miss.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to not go somewhere or do something, especially when you want to but cannot
miss.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I’m absolutely starving – I missed lunch.
He missed 20 games after breaking a bone in his wrist.
She was upset at missing all the excitement.
He had missed being elected by a single vote.
miss.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to fail to hit or catch an object that is close to you, or to fail to hit a distant object that you are aiming at
miss.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Every time she missed the ball she became more angry.
He fired, missed and loaded again.
The bullet narrowly missed her heart.
miss.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to feel sad because someone you love is not with you
miss.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: John will be sorely missed by his family and friends.
miss.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to feel sad because you do not have something or cannot do something you had or did before
miss.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I miss the car, but the bus system is good.
Ben knew he would miss working with Sabrina.
miss.translation[0].definitions[3].note_: Miss is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You say
I miss seeing you every day
I miss to see you every day
miss.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to be too late for something
miss.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: We got there late and missed the beginning of the movie.
I overslept and missed the train.
miss.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to not see, hear, or notice something, especially when it is difficult to notice
miss.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Perhaps there’s something the police have missed.
It’s a huge hotel on the corner. You can’t miss it (=it is very easy to notice or recognize).
You don’t miss much, do you  (=you are good at noticing things)?
John didn’t miss a trick (=noticed every opportunity to get an advantage) when it came to cutting costs.
miss.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to avoid something bad or unpleasant
miss.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: If we leave now we should miss the traffic.
They narrowly missed being killed in the fire.
As he crossed the street, a bus just missed hitting him.
miss.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to notice that something or someone is not in the place you expect them to be
miss.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: I didn’t miss my wallet till it came to paying the bill.
miss.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if an engine misses, it stops working for a very short time and then starts again
miss.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used as a polite way of speaking to a young woman when you do not know her name
miss.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Excuse me, miss, you’ve dropped your umbrella.
miss.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used by children when speaking to a female teacher, whether she is married or not
miss.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: an occasion when you fail to hit, catch, or hold something
miss.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Will he score a goal this time? No, no it’s a miss.
miss.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a young girl, especially one who has been bad or rude
miss.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: used in front of the family name of a woman who is not married to address her politely, to write to her, or to talk about her
miss.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: I’d like to make an appointment with Miss Taylor.
